awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial Intelligence (AI)-enabled Personalized Employability Curriculum (APEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project begins with an online self-assessment by middle-school girls to identify their innate interests within the fields of entrepreneurship, science, technology, or engineering. Current U.S. trends show a high attrition of girls with interests in these fields, beginning at the middle school level.  There is a subsequent drop-off over the ensuing academic years, and this results in small numbers of women occupying these types of roles in their adult careers. The assessment analysis and personalized roadmap will help clarify, support, and nurture the individual’s journey in their growth and development towards their career choices including careers in STEM and entrepreneurship. Ongoing refinement and enhancement of the assessment tool will help inform needed changes to the educational curriculum and/or shifts in societal thinking to help close the ongoing gap in women occupying highly skilled roles. The potential commercial and socioeconomic impact of the assessment and follow-on resources defines a marketable product with associated workforce that spans across the family, academic, governmental, and societal institutions. 


The technical innovation in this project is a unique framework assessing innate interest in the fields of entrepreneurship, science, technology, or engineering and leveraging these data to create a personalized artificial intelligence (AI)-driven career exploration, skills development, and employability curriculum. The goal is to confirm that the use of deep learning to provide these girls with a dynamic career exploration roadmap can successfully counter the common societal forces that negatively impact their pursuit of innate interests and development of the skills necessary for careers as entrepreneurs, scientists, technologists, and engineers. It is hypothesized that early identification of these innate interests preempts identity stereotypes. To combat confirmation bias that girls aren’t good at the fundamental skills needed for these careers, machine learning and AI-enabled data aggregation is used to correlate these innate traits with resources that foster associated job skills, offer opportunities and challenges that are suitable to the user, and provide opportunities to connect with successful role models to address the lack of representation of women in these areas. The initial scope of the project will target middle school girls and their parents/guardians with expansion to the broader audiences of teachers, mentors, coaches, and society in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
ESTE Leverage AI-Enabled Personalized Employability Curriculum (APEC)

ESTE Leverage, Inc., is developing an employability learning platform for unconventional learners to excel in the job market. The platform serves as a community tool for multiplying current and future employability options for preteens, parents, teachers, and professionals who are outside the conventional norms of education and associated employment. Phase I developed a novel psychometric assessment that identifies a Career Exploration Avatar which when used with emerging large language models, links to multiple personalized career pathways. The power in the assessment is in its underlying hypothesis that Entrepreneurial, Scientific, Technological, and Engineering thinking are natural outcomes of two or more individuals coming together to both either seek answers or seek questions. If the model can be widely applied, then every person regardless of gender, age, socioeconomic status, or identity has the opportunity to leverage these natural ways of thinking for any career of choice.  

Research has shown persistent gender differences in vocational interests and the pursuit of those interests which contribute to the unequal distribution of men and women in the labor market and their journey to get there. Males are found in Realistic and Investigative occupations while women are found in Artistic, Social, Conventional occupations. If a measure could be developed that prevents this separation by gender early on in their education, not only the reported bias against boys to be social and conventional in class be prevented, but the bias against girls choosing STEM careers would also be mitigated. ESTE has developed such a groundbreaking instrument in Phase I with its ESTE Is Innate Assessment, piloting it over 200 professionals and over 300 middle school students resulting in preliminary results demonstrating a valid and reliable instrument. Not only are Entrepreneurial, Scientific, Technological and Engineering thinking shown to be distinct mindsets, they are neutral to gender. These two outcomes, (1) mindset and (2) gender neutrality, have far implications for leveraging mindset rather than career personality for all underserved learners as well as leveraging mindset as the tool to explore career pathways while building self-efficacy towards ones career choices.

A patent provisional was filed during the Phase I that details the greater implications of the ESTE Framework and how it makes it accessible to all users. Thanks to its simple 2x2 design, the framework organizes different ways of thinking into two main dimensions: (1) the value a practitioner places on answers and questions and (2) the value society places on answers and questions. This setup maps out four mindsets - entrepreneurial, scientific, technological, and engineering - so that they reflect natural ways of thinking and problem-solving, rather than locking people into specific careers. This makes career exploration more personal and relational, meaning students can see how their unique skills fit with specific roles in relation to each other. This leads to a third (3) broad impact of the framework inherently including prosocial behavior in its relational properties. A fourth (4) broader impact is in the placement of Entrepreneurship level with STEM which has significant implications for fostering an innovative economy.  

While ESTE has been designing its adaptive learning platform for scalability and accessibility using its patent pending technology, both B2C and B2B Avatar with Exploration Roadmap sales have been growing for unconventional professionals in transition. B2C has included women returning to the workforce after raising their children, men and women choosing career pathways that defy gender stereotypes, men and women changing careers, and neurodivergents who thrive in personalized curricula. B2B has included visionary public K12 school superintendents open to leveraging their students' differences to build self-efficacy in job and career pursuits rather than to accept those differences as barriers to success in life as well as corporations, and businesses wanting to enhance team performance. Additionally, ESTE is expanding its products to support high school and college students.   


Last Modified: 11/01/2024
Modified by: Terrisa A Duenas

Image
  • The Framework is an analysis tool for assessing the combination of mindsets to a problem solution based on the relationship between those who value questions and those value answers. This gives rise to four combinations of relational value mapped onto four quadrants.
    Terrisa Duenas and Carmen Lamp
    Copyrighted
    Terrisa A Duenas
    ESTE Framework
